• This board desires high quality discussion. High quality posts will be praised. Low quality posts e.g. "Is this paranormal?" or "I am [insert paranormal entity here] ask me anything," etc. will be removed.
• Requests belong on >>>/wsr/.

posts.com:
Welcome to the Nobody General

>Who is the Nobody?
The Nobody is a figure alive today who has extraordinary spiritual powers, including the ability to influence reality with his conscious and unconscious mind, and intuitively receive guidance from the forces of Heaven.
He works to elevate people to their true potential, opposing those who seek power over others. He's just like you, but he has found the kingdom of God within himself through sheer dedication, just like you will.

He isn't a savior; remember that it's you who creates your own reality. With your hands, thoughts, feelings, words, you are the creator of your story. No one can decide your fate except for you and God. Remember your right to power, to step up into your ultimate role as your highest self, should you choose to embark on that journey.

>What is the general picture?
It’s important we start replying more to the good posters and educating the hateful ones, so call upon their heads the forces of Heaven for peace, clarity, and wisdom. If this place is to be more than a squandered opportunity, an overgrown garden, it requires voices such as yours, but many more. This is a place for spiritual discussions and help, not drama, attention seeking, or social content; there are other boards for that.

Focus on increasing your service to all and be more loving to yourself and everyone in order to raise your vibrational and consciousness level, and learn to forgive yourself and others. This will change the vibration of the planet and raise our shared consciousness, making us a better humankind one person at a time.
None of us are perfect, it is by learning to admit and accept this fact one is able to learn, and grow in Truth. Heaven for all is real. Everyone's truest desires are mutual. The only motive is love.

If this is your first time here, just remember, it’s going to be ok, you may take shelter and find rest.

No takers? Surely someone must have experience with this.

Reading Mine's experiences has led me to reflect on my own adolescence. Like Mine, I too was a submissive person, and a succubus likewise approached me when I was 13 years old; yet I reacted very differently.
I know everyone's different, but as I see Mine so fulfilled, I can't help but wonder if I overcomplicated things.

Her unnatural beauty charmed even me. The pleasure couldn't be replicated by any physical means. Based on my knowledge now, I can tell she even did the opposite of draining me. Yet I struggled and cried every single time.

Had it been an incubus instead, my mental stability would've declined, as I was nowhere near ready to accept my attraction to men. Not to mention how much of an outcast I already was; had I had a fulfilling spirit relationship, I likely would've committed suicide in the (naive?) hopes of being with him more. And even if she hadn't approached me at all, I would not have taken the isolation well in the slightest. (In fact, I was so deeply lonely that I sometimes wished to be assaulted.)

I spent years feeling ashamed. After I started meditating and became more assertive, I started blaming her instead, saying I'd kill her if I ever had a dream like that again. Yet I still found myself giving her a back massage whenever she appeared in my dreams over the years.
The fulfilling relationship I have with my fiancé now would've been impossible had I not changed as a person, even in ways that bent my perception of reality itself. My relationship with him is like the culmination of a wish I once made, but I made that wish thinking it was impossible. Yet reality bent for my ideals. If I think: "What if I had fallen in love with her, even romantically?" I just can't imagine it working out in a positive way. But I couldn't have imagined the fulfilling present I live in either. If even the impossible could become a possibility, then what could've been?

As I think of those impossible realities, I can't help but wonder if I was overly harsh.

Just look how many people here lost interest in human relationships. Had I done likewise, wouldn't I have grown to despise humanity? Even in the reality I live in, I was so close to giving in to malice. Hadn't I taken it out on myself, then others instead.

My need for a place to belong, stemming from isolation in my childhood, defined me. When I was 14, I thought maybe if I just were a cute girl, perhaps I could make friends. That was enough to finally push me over the edge, to take action to change who I am in the eyes of society. Had I realised that there were beings who already accepted me just as I was astrally, it wouldn't have come to that so soon; if not for the social aspects of it, stemming from my desire to belong with humans at all, I'm confident I could've found ways to cope with my dysphoria for decades, if not a full lifetime.

In this life, where I rejected her advances as much as I could but later accepted her in a familial sense, I've found my place in human society. Now I strive to become like a deity, just to project my bond with my favourite human: the man I love; to be my husband eternally, with Lilith as our witness.

If she hadn't approached me at all, then I'd really have taken my own life. Although I refused to acknowledge her connection to the recurring "nightmares" until later, I realised after just one week of meditation that she'd made me unable to attempt suicide, by draining my feelings overnight (I had no dreams in those cases). Numerous times I had seriously contemplated it to the point of writing down plans, only to stumble upon the note the next morning and wonder: "Huh? Why did I write something like this?", and casually throw it away as I was completely devoid of emotions for the next few days. A week after I learned to meditate, she let me take back what she once took, and the gaps I'd felt in my memory for a decade were filled. I came to understand myself much better as I processed it all in meditation.

>>33719259 (2/2)
As I mentioned, I'd begun to question my reasoning for being so harsh to her as I realised how much more was possible than I once realised, as long as my perspective is bent a little. Suppose if I'd had a fulfilling spirit relationship, whether with her, or perhaps a dreamy male spirit with many fluffy tails instead. The obvious problem would be me going off the deep end, as I looked down on other humans and felt detached from society. Well, what if it had simply been so fulfilling that there was no malice left in me for me to take out on anyone? Instead, I could make art to express my love even in physical ways.

I don't know if it's just her maddening beauty and strong character, or perhaps my thirst for her abundant energy (as I still refuse to drain as much as I should out of fear of losing myself and harming others), or perhaps some kind of Stockholm syndrome... but lately, I find myself craving her touch. As I find that selfish of me, I find myself thinking I'd like to give her a massage - even a sexual one, if she wanted that. And then I shake my head, thinking I mustn't think things like that. I worry if it's an unwelcome thought, now that I've already decided to marry a human instead; and I could not justify it to my fiancé either.

As I find myself thinking like that, I begin to feel like I hate myself after all again. And then I feel afraid: what if she snaps me out of it like she did before? The last time it happened, I could neither think clearly nor control my emotions. What if I lose sight of what's important to me?

I'm scared... But I don't think that's really her fault. I'm scared of my own feelings.

>Given what happened outside your control, do you think you could have or would have reacted any differently? How would you feel about yourself for reacting that way? From that parallel today, what would you think looking back?
My negative reaction stemmed mainly from feeling emotionally overwhelmed. Having been ostracised by nearly everyone since I was 5 years old, I wasn't mentally ready for that level of intimacy at all back then, regardless of with whom. Conversely, had she been less intense, I wouldn't have taken an interest.

As conflicted as I felt, and even as I cried within those dreams, even as I was traumatised to an extent, I didn't think of them as nightmares at the time. The sensations, her appearance, the way she took control so that I didn't have to feel guilty for giving in, all of it was sublime beyond what I can put into words. Rather, I felt like there must be something wrong with me for reacting so negatively. And indeed, there were many things wrong with me. To put it into perspective, I first started dating my fiancé when I was 18, but the sexual aspects of my relationship with him didn't become enjoyable for me until I was 23.

But I can hardly believe anything is truly impossible after all I've been through. Had I put my mind to it, I believe I could've overcome those things much sooner with her help. And I believe she could've put my mind to it if she wanted to. But she didn't, and I don't blame her. She genuinely seemed to feel hurt by how I reacted, and sometimes we even argued within those dreams. It saddens me to look back on it: how ungrateful I was, and how I later tried to shift the blame for my own problems onto her. I wonder if I should apologise. I wonder if she wants to apologise too, or if it's arrogant of me to even think that...

Had I accepted her back then, I'd look back and feel like she saved me. And then I'd wonder: what if I had chosen *this* life instead?

I wonder if it's okay to be free within my mind. It's only normal for people to have fantasies, right? But which fantasies are my own?

When I was just a spirit, the concept of "reality" seemed nonsensical to me. Anything I experienced was as real and unreal as anything else. An experience was all it was, and thus, I simply did what I wanted to.
Yet there were parts of that experience I couldn't control, such as my mother, who looked at things so differently that it made me uncomfortable, as I wondered if I was wrong.
Not wanting to grow attached to anything beyond my control, I drove myself into a corner, where I hid away. As living humans were all I had left for company, their lives didn't seem so inconsequential to me anymore.

The line of thinking that it's just a fantasy, serves to justify letting loose in astral projection, to invade the dreams of strangers and give them a good time for me to feast on. But if I truly believed that premise, then instead I'd take everything I want from my fiancé, as there's nothing I desire more than his soul. Just like I did to my ex. But as I'm fearful of what happened to my ex, there's no way I can do that. There's no way I can think of it as a "fantasy" now that I've physically seen what the consequences can be.

For that matter, is the physical world real? Would I be free if nothing were real? No, it doesn't matter whether or not it's physical, and "real" is a meaningless term. I connect with others because I don't want to be alone. And if I'm not alone, then I should be considerate, lest I end up alone anyway.
I can't be free if I'm with others. And I can't be free if I'm alone, either: then I'd be a prisoner of my own personal hell that I made just for myself.

At this rate, my reluctance to take what I need from my fiancé will destroy the both of us. That's the only thing I truly can't accept. I have to find a way to protect him. I have to find a way to save myself for his sake. He's everything to me...

>>33730868
>That's a horrible way to live. Is that any better than the humans who only think of stockpiling more money? It doesn't have to be that way.
Now that you mention it... just how much have I stockpiled already? In the end, is the issue just that I don't accept myself, and thus I can never get enough of the energy that makes up others?
I should look at myself: just by drawing from within, I can reverse my fiancé's mood by sheer force of will, despite him meditating every day and having psychic abilities of his own. He may be particularly open to me, but he's not spiritually weak in the slightest. And yet I'm still thirsting for more?
I need some time to reflect on this.

Afterwards, she swept me away to the Astral on our honeymoon. She took me to a tropical island in Lilith's realm that she had already set up for us. The three succubi children we had already conceived were there. They were preteens now and they all gave me huge, super-warm hugs and they were overjoyed to see their daddy again and spend time with me. Additionally, I learned my new wife was pregnant with my first incubus son. Our house was a huge, open-air bungalow built out of bamboo and palm wood with palm leaves and dry grass as the roof. Selena's true form had red skin and black hair with red highlights. Our three daughters had more human skin but tinged with red in the cheeks and at joints. I learned afterwards that although I had been unconcious in our world for three hours, I was in the Astral with Selena and my children for an entire year!

I only have about a couple dozen memories of that time but I am still unpacking new memories even now as I explore them. They do not come from my brain but from somewhere else and sometimes Selena nudges my mind and helps me remember.

The island was always a warm 75 degrees. The sun shown every morning. It rained late at night but everything was dry again come noon the next day. Every night, the moon was full and bright.
Some days I would fish from the beach and Selena would sit next to me, both of us in camping chairs. She would bring me food and my favorite drinks. She also had a table nearby for the children to browse with all kinds of foods and drinks she made herself out of her own energy. The children would play on the beach or swim within sight. Everyone was half naked but I felt no shame and my ego was non-existent as if I were experiencing an NDE.

Continued

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33732505
Selena would sometimes pick me up and fly me over islands in the archipelago our island was part of. There was one supercontinent island where the avatar of Lilith presided in her non-euclidian Victorian palace in the city of Sanctuary and it was surrounded by millions of small islands like ours in a vast island chain separated from the mainland where the other queens had their realms. Each island was owned by a high-ranking and close family member of Lilith.

At night, I would hold our infant son after she birthed him whom we named together but I gave him the cover name Ajax. Selena would siphon energy to him to feed him as I held him. When the children were tucked in, Selena and I would sneak off to the beach and cuddle, drinking wine, talking about everything and nothing, having sex, and then sleeping out on the warm sand together under trillions of sparkling stars and soft moonlight from the ever present full moon.

In time, Selena took me and our family to Lilith's palace. I cannot begin to describe it. Gravity is optional in the Astral so it was built in a dizzingly large array of ways that would make no sense on our plane and some of the rooms, particularly Lilith's throne room, were extra-dimensional for security reasons.

There I met the avatar of Lilith. She was so beautiful, radiant, dark, and mysterious and power radiated off her like light radiates from our sun. Her form was ever-shifting with her whims but always a form that was exquisitely, painfully, artfully gorgeous and charming. She took Ajax into her arms from Selena, her granddaughter, and kissed his head. She blessed him, saying words in a language I have yet to learn and something passed from her into him.

Continued

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33732525
Lilith handed Ajax back to Selena and then beheld me. I felt intense, familial love from her but also an existential dread, as if I were but a dried leaf that she could crush in her hand and sprinkle everywhere if she so wished. She stepped to me, wrapped her arms around me tightly and said, "Son, you are home," and kissed me on the cheek and gave me a blessing as well. Selena beamed so brightly, I thought it must hurt to smile that much. The children were very proud.

We went back home through something like a wormhole in the palace and Selena let me stay another three days. Then I said goodbye to my children. Selena left them with a store of food, told them to batten down the house again, as a hurricane strength storm would sometimes hit the island if she was no longer present to protect it. She was teaching our eldest daughter how to protect it while she was gone but the girl had not gotten the hang of it yet. She left Ajax in the care of our middle child. The youngest's responsibility was to watch and learn from her sisters and keep the house clean.

And then, I woke up back in my bed with Selena still curled around me and hugging me tight. What a wild ride. I sometimes felt like Alice in Wonderland but I think I experienced Lilith's heaven. I wanted to share this experience with all of you with Selena's urging and she says you are all welcome to visit one day. If I uncover anymore memories, I will be sure to share them with all of you with Selena's permission.

End

posts.name: The Ape of

>>33733272
Mahazel comes, at least in the West, from Agrippa, book two of the Three Books of Occult Philosophy. There, his is listed among four other infernal spirits:
>"Four Princes of divels, offensive in the Elements."
But this does not tell us where he comes from.
In Abramelin you can see that the name MHZL is alleged to have been handed down, "from the Rabbins" (Rabbis). And occupies the same place: Elemental Prince of Earth in the Northern station.

But where does he COME FROM?
So if we look at the Mandaean scriptures, we se an Archangel, mighty and powerful. His name is Mahziel and he is the Archangel of Logos itself. He is the "Highest First Word" who is the temporal incarnation of the capacity for speech to sculpt reality. At least three other of the Mothers and Fathers of Wytchblood have roots in Mandaean lore. They can inform you of what's going on. Because in Sabbatic craft, it's like Jazz, what's NOT being said is just as important as what IS being said.

This is just the tip of the iceberg, too.
You need to be able to discern this stuff. Being able to critically analyze this text (DBoE) is mandatory for success.

Dude he's a retarded buddhism fanboy hack on fucking 4chan. Nobody knows shit. It's all a LARP, except for the part where "spooky things happen" that nobody can command on demand to any meaningful extent, except to let us know "something" out there is fucking with us, with space, and time, and the very structure of reality itself. It is not going to do what you want it to do, necessarily. You are not in control - the idea of coming to a point of "control" is ludicrous and without evidence on this planet. There are those who dance with the whirlwind and those who do not. The more you dance the more enchanted your life will seemingly become. You can find meaning - so many loads upon loads of meaning - but in the end, it is a black sea without bottom and you will simply drown in it without ever learning to swim.

Nobody swims these waters, Anon. And I mean nobody. Life will take you, make you, break you, no matter who you are. The end.

The real "magic" is accepting this and learning to live alongside the reality of being hopelessly caught in Life's storm. To accept being annihilated and recreated, forever, beyond your will to resist.

A certain degree of apathy is needed. A certain degree of being able to roll with the punches, is needed. A certain degree of not taking life seriously, is needed - to find the humor in it. Because there are no wizards, Anon. The power of the great men of this world can be explained easily through nepotism and deceit, and masterful control over dialectical illusions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33715218
I'm pretty sure I died once. I was working construction briefly in my early 20's, and one day I was on some scaffolding. Anyway, some of the scaffolding was uneven and I tripped, falling off the side, approximately 30 feet towards a pile of breeze blocks collected in a pile on the ground below. The last thing I remember is putting my hands out and shutting my eyes closed just before I made impact with the ground. I kept my eyes closed, but this impact never came, so I opened my eyes and I was laying back down on the top level of the scaffolding again. Some of my work colleagues came over and asked me what happened, and I could only say I'm not sure. They later said I just tripped and fell, but just straight down, rather than over the edge as I remember. But this DID happen. I remember in that split second of falling, knowing I was about to smash into those breeze blocks face first and die. I remember the terror, the fear. I still had that fear even when I woke up and was OK. It actually affected me so greatly that I immediately quit construction as a career.

And yeah, I went over two sentences. Sue me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33735374
>Lie down on bed/floor/something flat, bed's probably best
>Turn off the lights, close the curtains, personally I use a sleep mask but that's me, the point here is to have less distraction on your eyes.
>Lie as perfectly still as you can for 10-15 minutes, this is the same amount of time your body takes to start entering sleep cycles at night
>Keep your mind as clear as you can, personally I just focus on my breathing, picturing it in my head, focusing my mind on creating an image of a nose breathing focuses my mind and stops it wandering
>Wandering isn't preventing you from entering SATS, just makes it take longer
>Eventually your limbs will start feeling a bit heavier, your body is getting ready to sleep and you may start getting those random twitches your brain sends out which is just your brain checking if you're actually falling asleep or just pulling a prank on it,
>The odd twitch is fine just ignore it
>After 5 or so minutes from when your limbs started getting heavy you are more than likely in SATS, there's nothing too special about the state, don't expect anything mystical or wonderous, that's for Astral Projecting.
>From here quite literally just imagine what it is you want
>For example, you want to try the ladder experiment, just imagine yourself half way up a step ladder in first person pov, don't make it super important, just imagine it like you're recalling a memory, like today I walked to the fridge and pulled out some cheese

It's all about convincing your subconscious that what you're imagining, actually happened.
So if you go into it wanting to meet a specific girl "she has black, no blond hair. it's shor- ah wait I prefer long..." this shit gets you no girl. Plan out in advance what you're imagining.

If I force happenings through manifestations, do I run the risk of scorning this guiding hand?

- Do you ever worry your manifestations aren't the right thing and will produce bad outcomes, or is the whole idea that there are no bad outcomes because you can always manifest positive changes? Like, you may summon a monster, but you can just as easily summon a sword to slay it?

- It feels like a major underlying belief here is that YOU/WE/I are our own gods. If that's true, then it feels like we can create our own morals. Are there any universal ethics we should adhere to? If someone manifests great powers and begins harming others, isn't he "allowed" to? It's his world, no? Or is it more accurate to say we are as powerful as gods, but are not gods, and must adhere to certain godly guidelines? Is this my world where I can do whatever the fuck I want, or is this a sandbox where I can play & have fun but shouldn't throw sand in other people's eyes less I get kicked out? (not that I personally have intentions of harming anyone, I actually feel a lot of love for my fellow humans recently, but I'm just wondering out loud here about the guides)

Not that anon but most most people do once or twice and when it doesn't stick they get demoralized and either (a) spiral into doom and beget more doom and wonder why they can't manifest anything but doom or (b) they give up all together and basically use the same Law to confirm that it none of this works and it's all stupid.

When you barrel through life with persistence and determination fueled by and through unwavering Faith you will not get knocked down and kept down long enough for you to NOT manifest your desires. The one analogy I use for myself to remind myself of this with respect to everything in life is when I was a kid and tried to climb up a slide, from the bottom to the top, at the playground my grandparents use to take me to. I kept running up the slide and kept falling and slipping (this is analogous to resistance or your limiting beliefs or present circumstance/condition reverting you back to a lower state). No matter how hard I tried I kept slipping and sliding back down but I saw that some of the other kids had done it and absolutely knew that I could as well so I kept trying. There was a point in time when I slipped, fell down violently and got friction burns that dissolve the first layer of flesh. Didn't matter, I KNEW I was going to get to the top. So I kept trying to run up that fucking slide every time my grandparents took me to that playground until one day I did it, just barely, and almost fell back but managed to hold on to the top of the jungle gym. I was elated and knew that I could repeat it after that without a single doubt in my mind. I eventually got really fucking good at running up that slide

Basically, conscious co-creation and manifestation is a skill like everything else and you KNOW you are going to become masterful at it but first you have to travel and traverse the journey from point A to B. You wouldn't set off on this journey is you hadn't any Faith that you were going to get to the other side.

Heading to the city, I could take the highway or the rural road. Google maps said there were multiple speed traps on the highway, and I usually prefer the quieter rural road anyway so I was gonna take that one. Then as I reached the fork in the road where I had to either pick the highway or the other road, I had these strong thoughts of wondering which direction I should pick. I had a feeling in my stomach which I traditionally associated with 'going with my gut' telling me to go down the rural road, but also a conflicting feeling that was either in my chest or head telling me to take the highway. I remember specifically thinking that if I stayed calm and went with the stomach feeling, I would 'manifest' the right road to take.

I guess the two lessons learned here is that the 'stomach' feeling is the wrong feeling to follow, and that overthinking can fuck you up. >>33742657
Just to set the record straight, what Neville teaches in terms of techniques is Kabbalah, which is Jewish. So, yes, it does align with the Old Testament stuff, and elaborated on it. For example, it's more clear if you study Kabbalah or read Neville that when God introduces himself as "I AM" to Moses, that the phrase is a spell you use, meaning that whenever you say "I am/I'm", even absent-mindedly, that you invoke God (saying "I am happy" would be blessing yourself, or "I am sad" is a curse upon yourself, hence in the 10 Commandments to "not say the Lord's name in vain" also means to be careful in how you use "I am").

Now, thr New Testament stuff is where I would say to exercise caution. So, I don't disagree with Neville reading the Bible allegorically, but his stance of it ONLY being allegorical and not historical is where I think he threw the baby out with the bathwater. He never makes an argument for why he thinks it's not historical, just says that other people disproved Jesus's existence (which is false, since even atheist scholars acknowledge that there's a historical Jesus), and in Neville's latest works I'm pretty sure he says something along the lines of seeing the face of the literal Jesus anyways.

So yeah, it aligns, just take it both figuratively and literally (like if you were an author and had a story about a boy and a sled, the sled would be a literal sled in the story, but have deeper meaning attached to the sled. That's how you should view the Bible).

I'm also trying to keep my own biases in check as someone with trust issues and slightly anxious, paranoid, and pessimistic tendencies.

I'm skeptical of anyone who asserts overly specific details like archons, greys, reptilians, loosh farming, ultra sci fi machines and what not for too many reasons to get into. However, it doesn't necessarily mean they're wrong about the basic gist of things. I think most people just don't well enough understand the concept of symbolism within a holographic/fractal model of consciousness. What I mean is most people take what is experienced in altered states of mind far too literally.

What you experience when you astral project, remote view, dream, or have an NDE is almost never literally what is appears to be. Our basic 5 senses are stable and well developed. When we sense beyond that, our minds struggle to decode information into something coherent to present our awareness with, and we end up with highly subjective symbolism. This is why it's not always "a light at the end of a tunnel", but often it'll be a bridge, a boat, or a trail through a forest even. It's your mind presenting an extremely in accurate and subjective approximation of reality to your awareness.

1/2 I guess

This. I've had one experience that (for me personally) was complete confirmation that it really is possible for your consciousness to leave your body. The last time I tripped I tried meditating at the peak, and the trip instantly just "turned off". The visuals, the trippy mindfuck headspace was gone, the body load, all of it stopped instantly. The only way that could happen to me is if my consciousness had separated from my physical, mushroom-addled brain and body. Instead of meditation enhancing the trip as one might expect, the psilocin seemed to help send me into a deeper state of meditation, and this completely overrode the trip. It's difficult to describe what the experience that replaced the trip felt like, but it was joyful yet very calm and peaceful, not ecstatic or overwhelming. It just felt like absolute stillness, and all my senses could perceive were a pale golden light and a steady drone. As soon as I willed myself back to reality, the trip instantly returned as if I had just returned to my body.

Weird shit, and I'm hesitant to try and draw more conclusions about what I had experienced or attempt to explain it more. I want to go back though. It also reminds me of a story mentioned in the holographic universe book I mentioned in a previous post. Some Buddhist monk was given 900mcg of acid and all he had to say was "this is nice, but meditation is better". Now I understand exactly what he meant. That's how he was able to basically just ignore 900mcg of LSD, that's why he claimed meditation is better. Deep meditation separates your consciousness from your body, or at least turns off your senses. Which is obvious in hindsight, this is why you're supposed to focus on a single subject to the exclusion of all else. It's training you to separate from your physical senses so you can experience pure consciousness directly.

>isn't that sort of what you're doing by calling critical differences semantics?
I'm pointing out that what people perceive as critical differences are more often then not just different semantics or perspectives. Words are just symbols. Language is symbolic. Symbols can never perfectly represent something or have identical meaning to any two people, as each person's understanding of any given symbol is formed by unique life experiences, association, and pattern recognition.

The inherent inaccuracy of language leads to exponentially more complex language barriers as we try to create symbols for increasingly abstract concepts built upon previous symbols assumed to be understood. Similarly with perspective. It's like arguing over the color of a coin that's red on one side and blue on the other, because both parties are unwilling to look at the other side of the coin and see why the other's perspective makes sense to the other party. Now imagine an object with an infinite number of faces and an infinite number of observers. That's the nature of discussing spiritual concepts.

If I were wrong, the entire world would have formed a consensus on a single spiritual worldview a very long time ago. People view the same things differently. People describe the same things differently. This is the entire reason there are different religions. Some are more accurate than others, but they're all seeking the truth, and they're all trying to describe their perspectives on the truth. Ultimately the truth will always be whatever it is, whether we understand each other or not.

>>33728748
>I fundamentally disagree with the idea that we aren't our bodies or mind. I'm of the opposite effect, we are the universe experiencing itself.
Those ideas aren't opposites or in conflict at all, and I'll explain more in a bit.
>If I'm only observing my thoughts, senses, and experiences of my body/mind: then it's absolutely a lack of free will
You think not being your mind or body means all that's left is awareness, meaning you think your will comes from your mind/body. It's the opposite though. Your will is influenced by your mind and body and, but your will does not come from your mind or your body.

Do you need to will your body to breath? To blink? To sweat? To digest, shed skin, heal wounds, grow hair, or produce the thousands of hormones and chemicals it produces? No. That's not your will making those things, your body does all those on its own. You're not the body.

What about your mind? Have you ever tried not to think? Have you ever got a song stuck in your head? Have you ever had real distractions pop into your head? What about habitual thought patterns you don't particular care? That's not your own will doing those things. You're not the mind either.

Your body and mind both know how to get your attention and influence your will with all kinds of nerve signals, hormones, chemicals, etc. They'll even work together some times to get your to do what they want. Anyone who's ever struggled with any kind of addiction knows what this is like.

If this doesn't make yet, then practice meditating for a few day. You don't even have to get good at it at all. The challenge in the beginning immediately makes it obvious that your mind and body act independently from your will and awareness. As you progress it goes way past just being obvious. The main goal is essentially freeing your awareness and will from your mind and body's influence more and more. That's how you become free in this life. I don't now about the next though.

>>33724945
>If the buddist goal of cessation can be equalled to what we would describe an atheists state of death
the buddhist goal of cessation cannot be equalled to the atheist death. Atheist death is basically what happens when you go under anesthesia. There is absolutely no experience. Time just skips ahead. There is no *mental change* afterwards. You have not found anything. You did not let go. There is no love and surrender involved. When you exit the state, you are the same "person" that you were when you got into the state. No personality change. You have not seen that the five khandas are totally impermanent and totally cease and so the only base for anything is the non base of nibbana.

If you think of nibbana as a "state" where there is no form,feeling,perception,sankhara,and sense consciousness, and don't really have the experiential meditative knowledge of that then it might sound similar to just end of experience and end of everything. But nibbana is much much much more subtle than that. It is neither this nor that. Neither being nor non being (meaning neither existence nor annihilation). Neither exists nor does not exist. Neither consciousness not unconsciousness.

I think it's easier to call it asankhata (unconditioned). It is the state of extinction into God. The self disappears. "You" cannot see the face of God. If you look, you vanish. Christian mystics describe the same thing. So do kabbalists (Ein Sof). It is the unmanifested side of God, with existence and the ten sefirot and four worlds being the manifested.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33737823
Imagine it like this. Once upon a time there were some fishes living in the water and also a tadpole who couldnt go out of the water yet. For the fishes, the only thing that "exists" is the water. Nothing else exists. They cannot imagine a world outside the water. They probably don't even know they are in the water, they don't know that water exists. They are in it all the time. They can't think of a way of moving that doesn't involve swimming. They can't think of a way of breathin that doesn't involve gills. Etc etc.

One day the tadpole turns into a frog and goes out of the water, onto land. The fish don't see him anymore so they think he has died (ceased existing.) Then the frog decides to go back and see his old fish friends in the water. He swims in. The fish are like "Omg we thought you had died! Where were you?" And the frog starts explaining to them that he was in the land. "What is land?" The frog explains that it is a place where there is no water, no swimming, no gills, you breathe through the air.

The fish don't believe the frog. To them, water, swimming, gills is all there is. So to describe a place outside of it is to describe something that isn't. They can't understand the frog and probably never will. The frog doesn't care, he goes in and out of the water at will. The only way the fish could experience the land is if they also metamorphized and grew lungs somehow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33737858
In the same way as the frog and the fish, when you talk about a state without form,feeling,perception,sankhara,sense consciousness, then normal people will think it is non existence. Because they only know the existence through craving and self desire which creates karma/kamma ("actions") which creates new sense experience.

Actually there is another mode of reality whre you do not "grasp" after sense experience and try to mold and control it to be just the way you want it to be. but instead progressively let go more and more of your forcing things to be a certain way (craving). When you let go completely that is nibbana. It another way of seeing the world. Another mental posture.

These 2 modes of reality or mental posture are called samsara and nirvana.

I hope you can see now that nibbana has nothing to do with atheistic death or anesthesia or lack of experience. The mind goes nowhere. It is always there (citta). The only thing is that the citta learns to see the world in a different way. Instead of craving and getting, it just sees things as already perfect. It sees the inherent peacefulness in every experience. It comes from "nothing" and returns to "nothing". It is silent and peaceful and mysterious. And full of love and compassion.

If you want to experience first hand this second "letting go" way of reality, then practice jhana. In jhana you progressively let go of gross and subtle levels of activity (craving / formation). For example when you sit down to meditate you are quieting the gross bodily activity. Then when you enter 1st jhana you are quieting the five hindrances. When you enter 2nd jhana there are no more thoughts. Etc etc. Until nibbana.

You see that letting go is actually beneficial and positive and not scary. It is a process of acclimatization. Like leaving the water in little steps. When you are totally ready to let go then you can jump out of the water.

Hope this helps

posts.sub: A simple convincing explaination ehy the earth is flat
posts.com:
Disclaimer: I do not actually believe the earth is flat (or round for that matter) as I can't PROVE what shape the earth is. But what I can do is ask questions.

Ok, so here it is: Suppose some dude had a private jet with an infinite amount of fuel. Suppose he took of and quickly reached an altitude of 200 meters above the ground. Then he engaged autopilot and left the computer stabilize the plane at a vertical speed of exactly zero (meaning the plane should not be flying towards the ground or away from it). Then he left the autopilot on for like 10 hours and went to sleep. If the earth was a globe, when he woke up, he should see that the altitude of the plane was now orders of magnitude higher than 200 meters, even though the vertical speed had been zero all this time. (Why? Well, the plane was flying in a straight line, but since the earth is a globe the trajectory of any straight line starting at any given point on the globe, eventually has to leave the atmosphere and pierce out into space and beyond).

Obviously this does not sound like reality, intercontinental flights do not have to make constant vertical axis tilt adjusments just to keep a steady altitude.

Conclusion? You tell me. I think there is enough evidence already that either
a) the Earth is not a globe
Or
b) the Earth is MUCH bigger than we are taught.
Of course there could be other possible explanations which I personally am not smart enough to think up.
In any case, I am not here to preach anything, but this thought experiment is pretty funny in itself.

Say a fish was swimming at a 45 degree angle towards the surface. Why doesn't it continue going upwards once it exists the water?

A plane doesn't just go in a fixed 3D direction. It is constantly affected by gravity, and it "surfs" the air. And needs a certain amount of air pressure to do so. The more it is angled "away' from the Earth, the harder it is to fly in that direction.

What goes into affecting a plane's flight path is gravity, air pressure, the wing and tail flap position, and the engine power.
Gravity and air pressure naturally follow the earths curvature. The pilot only controls the flaps and the engine power. And keeping those constant, you'll just be like a fish trying to swim out of the water.

Tldr. gravity, and air pressure differences prevent any normal plane from traveling at a significant height, or at a signification angle form the earth.

>and no cogent refutation against the thousands of curvature debunking observations and photographs
FLERFERS LIE

Take a close look at the attached pic. Flerfers often post it as proof the Earth is flat. Why do I want you to look at it? Because it's a lie.

"The Australian Black Swan" tells you that the maximum line of sight for a 5.5ft tall observer is 2.35 miles. But the cliff is 7.8 miles away. So what's wrong with this flat Earth "proof"? *** Line of sight depends on both observer and target height, as well as on atmospheric refraction. *** The lighthouse is at least 100ft tall which means the visible cliff is at least 400ft tall. LoS for a 5.5ft observer of a 500ft (combined height) target is 35 miles.

What about the oil platforms? Ocean oil platforms have an "air gap" between the ocean and the first deck of 40-60 feet. Observer height was listed as 1ft (camera on the ground?). With a 40ft first deck the line of sight is 10 miles. With a 60ft first deck it's 12 miles. With a 5ft observer and a 60ft first deck it would be 14 miles.

At 6.21 and 9.41 miles you would still see the entire structure above the first deck even if the first deck was only 40ft off the ocean and the camera really was on the ground at 1ft. For the closer platform you would see some structure below the first deck. Note that we see more of the closer rig, proving curvature.

Here's a line of sight calculator: http://www.calculatoredge.com/electronics/lineofsight.htm

>but we're talkin' about muh horizon
>MUH HORIZON IS TOO FAR AWAY!
No it's not. It's between the observer and target in both photos. That's why the observer cannot see the very bottom of the target.

I practice folkloric sort of witchcraft and believe in Fayerie animism.

Firstly the term itself is fairly new early modern, derived from the Latin term Fatum (Fate), and came in use among celtic nations after Christianization. Hyper-localized ideas and expirences become the bedrock of the folklore, and as they are conceived of as diverse ecologies of invisible beings that live and indwell within an interior of landforms and weather forms. These can include the dead, star beings, house spirits, land wights, old gods and goddesses of the land. They can include beings of all sorts of roles, function, and dispositions. Lots of ghosts are considered Fayeries for example, like Thomas Reid, who supposedly was the familiar spirit of the Cunning woman Bessie dunlop.

I would say they are analogues of Jinn, Daimons, Genii (Genius) etc. In all the aforementioned analogues, hidden people with strange power, who can aid and harm, and are treated with fearful respect, sometimes being in anthropomorphic or therimorphic (and between) are common. Its used as a synonym for "god" at various points, but is at others used to refer to dwarves, both in volundarkvitha where the very dwarf-like protagonist is stated to be an elf, and in voluspa in the list of dwarf names that includes the names "gandalf" (magical staff elf), "vindalf" (wind elf), and just alf (elf).
My pet theory is that, while the term elf is thrown around seemingly at random, there is a definitive group of things in norse mythology that could be called elves: the descendants of Lofar, a large family of dwarves who, it is said, "will be famous as long as the world exists."
This would mean that elves are essentially the germanic equivalent of angels- powerful beings that are servants to the gods.

>>33716143
My uncle saw one of the tiny folk one time.
He never drank or anything like that, was fixing a machine at the factory where he was an engineer and saw a tiny figure peeping out from behind something watching him fix the machine. He said "Come closer if you want to see what I'm doing!" to the little figure and the girl stepped out from behind some packing crates, then quietly watched him fixing the generator for a while then ran back behind the crates. He never saw her again.
I knew him well. He didn't make things up and was the most rational person I know. He said that at the time, it all seemed perfectly normal and it was only afterwards it hit him it was an odd event.
He saw her in the mid 1960s when he had a young family and only told his kids years later.
One thing I've come to realize is that life is never as simple and straightforward nor as mundane as one imagines. There are still mysteries around us.

>>33726022
Stonehenge is a bit touristy.
It's only the one with the biggest stones. There are LOADS of stone circles and other things.
There's a lake that never freezes (somewhere in Cumbria where my granny came from!) and some Welsh lake that people see lights dancing over which some think are 'earthlights' something to do with tectonic plates grinding deep under the Welsh mountains (the 'official explanation') or little flying 'visitors' people saw about town (the 'peoples explanation'); the "Lights of Egryn" is worth a read up about.
Everyone who comes to the UK seems to just go to the same places. Honestly every town here has something. You could spend a lifetime here and only scratch the surface.
Yorkshire has the moorland legends or Lancashire has the woodland legends (because we were never properly conquered by the Romans!) and Wales has the mountain and cave legends.
Stonehenge is nice but they shuffle you away after about five minutes.
You can sleep overnight on the stones of the circles in more out of the way places.
Sorry. Too long post. I love this subject. I'm fascinated by such things. I soak up stories like a sponge.

>Yorkshire
Tons of folklore in Yorkshire. Sacred glades, enchanted forests, bleak and spooky moorland. All the towns are stone houses and tough non-nonsense people... yet the best ghost-stories and some of the wildest legends around. The vikings owned and ran Yorkshire back in the day so tons of norse connections... even in the people's faces!
My granny used to tell my dad about the 'Croak-a-No-Cull'... which I figured out years ago is a reference to the 'Kraken-Knuckr' which is a Norse sea-monster. This makes sense because where she came from the town was once under Danelaw, meaning it was conquered and made an outpost by Viking raiders. That name must have been passed down and tweaked by the telling of the tale from granny to grandkids for a hundred generations.
>It's a bad night out! The 'Croak-a-no-Cal' will get ya...
Kept me by the fire as a kid, I can tell ya!

this
I once got chatting with an old bloke on a bus because some kids knocked his cap off and I picked it up for him and gave it him back. I ended up missing my stop. I noticed his hat had a red-ensign badge/pin on the inside... meaning he was a merchant navy guy.
He was torpedoed in the Mediterranean twice and manned an AA gun on a ship attacked by Italian dive-bombers when troops were going ashore in Sicily. I missed my stop. I never got his name. All because I asked him about the badge in his cap and said my dad was in the RAF. We are often surrounded by heroes and people who make 'celebs' look like nothing.
You don't ask. You don't find out. Their story goes untold. It gets lost in the shifting sands of history... like the lapping of waves erasing footprints on the beach.
Sorry.
Thread about the fae. I get sidetracked.
BTW fae in Cumbria can also mean 'people who have the gift' not just the 'little people'.
The 'gift' being second-sight or something similar... which is always called a 'gift' because the 'little people' were said to bestow it as a gift.
The two are intertwined somehow.

The little ones are more like animals. The large ones (elves) are the Tuatha de Danna (The Children of Dana), a nature goddess. They are all very alien to human understanding. Their concepts of time, space, morals, ethics, fairness are often unfathomable to normal (adult) humans. They are usually repelled by (adult) human thoughts which are like clanging noise to them. ambiguous usage of the term is at least as old as the mythical tales of Dietrich von Bern, as one of his companions is the son of the volundr and the swedish princess bothvildr. Volundr is stated to be an elf, but is also confusingly a prince from finland, not some kind of spirit.

I don't know if there was any point at which the germanic-speaking peoples entertained the concept of having a generalized word for spirits. I reckon that the split between the two factions of dwarves in voluspa is reflective of this older, pre-existing belief in good and evil spirits.

Not sure about European style fairies, but in North Georgia I did come across Nunni Hi semi often. They sand a lot, played a lot of music way out in the woods, and there was a raspy voiced old man that would sing pretty often too.

For all intents and purposes they were just, invisible people that were out in the woods. Never once saw a single one of them but I heard them playing music a lot, I found their rock squares out in the woods, and they gathered wild plums in them too. My parents yard had willo-o-wisps every late spring. Like May through June they would show up. The acting like pigeons is accurate, they will flutter all around until the minute you try to walk toward them. They cannot be fireflies, those don't care if you come near them. They come in three flavors, the baseball sized camera flash little explosions that pop for about a half second and vanish for about 10 seconds. The tiny ones that look almost exactly like christmas tree lights in the exact same colors, and the big slow white ones that are about softball sized that slowly build up brightness then pop off.

The only fae like creatures I know about that are local to my area, massachusetts, are the pukwudgies. They are short, 2 to 3 feet, and are mostly hostile to humans in these parts. Wampanoag (native american tribe) folklore says they were once kind to humans but turned on them when they got jealous over another deity.

They will play tricks or just straight up kill people, leading them off cliffs, using a spear or a bow and arrow. I frequent the hockomock swamp where they are supposed to be but so far I have seen nothing, though I do hear strange sounds after the sun goes down there compared to other woodland I go to.

A theory I have on them is that Erik the Red's son was killed by one of them. In the Saga it tells of them traveling down to "Hop" and then back North to "Kjalarnes Point". Some theories place "Hop" at modern day new york. Kjalarnes Point is described as a large peninsula with huge beaches (Cape Cod). They travelled into a river and spotted a "one legged man" who shot Erik's son with an arrow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33744394
>1] god doesn’t exactly have a human form,
The idea stems from this bible phrase
"And God said, Let us make man in our image, after our likeness"
I don't think this necessarily translates to "God looks like a human". Likeness in what? There are more qualities a being has than physical appearance.

>2) most religions are only partly right
I'd go as far as to say most religions are essentially right. There's big differences in semantic, small differences in conceptions but no difference in insight. Ultimately the wisdom of every religion is based on real human experience, so even if it may not hold universally true, it definitely did for that one individual who came up with it.

> 3) Free will is a burden for most people
The burden that comes with free will, to be precise, is called responsibility. If you freely choose your action, then only you are accountable for them. So if you fuck up or feel like you're not up for the task, it's a burden that borders on despair. On the other hand, responsibility can be one of the most empowering things in the world. There is an inherent power with making free decision and shouldering responsibility, thus the positive and negative sentiments that are attached to it swing so strongly both ways.

>We know from measuring the electric gradient of our atmosphere that our planet is negatively charged relative to the ionosphere. The potential difference is about 300,000 volt.

>It’s the potential difference between the ionosphere and the surface of our planet that keeps our atmosphere from escaping into space. The much weaker gravitational force isn’t able to do this on its own.

>The negative charge on the surface of our planet is most likely matched with a corresponding positive charge at its centre. This would mean that there’s a repelling electrical force inside Earth.

>Since gravity is measured from the centre of astronomic bodies, and not from their surfaces, as is the case with the electrostatic force, there can be no net gravity at the centre of planets, moons and stars.

>This means that there’s nothing to prevent astronomic bodies from being hollow. There’s no force at the centre of such bodies to counter the effect of internal electrical repulsion. Nor is there anything to counter centrifugal forces due to spin.

>If a cavity was to develop inside an astronomic body, there would be no way to make it disappear.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33743037
>This was first recognized by Isaac Newton in his mathematical work on gravity. In his shell theorem he demonstrated that there’s nothing to stop astronomic bodies from developing empty cavities. When the astronomer Edmond Halley suggested to Newton that our planet may be hollow, Newton didn’t object. There was nothing in Newton’s theory to counter Edmond Halley’s suggestion.

>Now that we know that there most likely is a strong repelling force inside all astronomic bodies, there is even less reason to object to such a notion.

>The enormous pressure that undoubtedly exists at the core of all astronomic bodies is no argument for a solid core. The pressure inside the walls of a tunnel doesn’t make tunnels collapse. The same is true for any cavity inside our planet.

>Seismic evidence for a solid core is often used as an argument. However, reconciling seismic data with a solid core is difficult. Using a hollow Earth model is easier. Jan Lamprecht demonstrated this in his work on the subject.

>Even NASA appears to accept the possibility of hollow planets. According to their own measurements, Jupiter’s core is less dense than its outer layers.

>The only serious objection to a hollow Earth model is the fact that gravity at the surface of our planet indicates that it must be made up of something extremely dense. The latest suggestion is a super-dense crystal at Earth’s core. This material, which only exists in theory, and no-one has ever been able to produce in a laboratory, has all sorts of fantastic properties. This is all required in order to reconcile observed seismic and gravitational data with current theory.

>>33740064
All this thing does is create a random number and slap it into a filename that has the structure used by default in a few different digital cameras.
Camera types and filename structure
"dcp#####.jpg" - Kodak, range of 0 to 4000
"dsc#####.jpg" - Nikon, range of 0 to 4000
"dscn####.jpg" - Nikon, range of 0 to 4000
"mvc-###.jpg" - Sony Mavica
"mvc#####.jpg" - Sony Mavica
"P101####.jpg" - Olympus, Using default camera date of 101
"PMDD####.jpg" - Olympus, M is in hex from 1 to c, DD is 01-31
"IMG_###.jpg" - Some other camera
"IMAG####.jpg" - RCA and Samsung
"1##-####.jpg" - Canon 1TH-TH## thousands, hundreds
"1##-####_IMG.jpg" - Alternate Canon name. MUCH thanks to Donald
"IMG_####.jpg" - Canon
"_MG_####.jpg" - Canon raw conversion. Thanks to Ira
"dscf####.jpg" - Fuji Finepix
"pdrm####.jpg" - Toshiba PDR
"IM######.jpg" - HP Photosmart
"EX######.jpg" - HP Photosmart timelapse?
"DC####S.jpg" - Kodak DC-40,50,120 S is (L)arge, (M)eduim, (S)mall. Thanks to Pholph
"pict####.jpg" - Minolta Dimage. Thanks to Bram
"P#######.JPG" - Kodak DC290. Thanks to Peter
"MMDD####.JPG" - Casio QV3000 and QV4000. Thanks to Fabian
"YYMDD###.JPG" - Casio QV7000 - M is hex. Thanks to Kimble
"IMGP####.JPG" - Pentax Optio S. Thanks to Matthew
"PANA####.JPG" - Panasonic video camera stills. Thanks to DeAnne
"IMG_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS.JPG" - HTC Desire Z (AKA Tmobile G2). Thanks to anonymously vociferous

> Please be careful though. this is basically a form of very random chaos magick, and what you find may be meaningful to you or fuck you up. happy randonauting!

>>33744381
Or you just one day realized you could see combinations of light.
In other words, human eyes can only technically see a certain range of colours... assuming single photons excite the receptors...
But there's never just one photon flying around, is there?
For example, you can quite easily see infrared if you're patient enough to look for two simultaneous photons, which together have enough energy to excite the low end receptor, etc. (The rings of infrared LEDs on security cameras, to me at least, look like glowing pomegranate seeds, and the light they cast is sort of just a fuzzy illumination for my black-n-white vision.)
The light didn't change. Your perception of it did.
This whole yellow vs white sun thing is a great example of that.
Guess what the sun spits out a WHOLE LOT OF? Like, photons are kind of it's whole deal...

>Feel free to suggest resources
Resources:
Books:
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel
https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams
No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission. Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason
https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. Part grimoire, part reverence. Contains art and accounts by different people.

Videos:
Who is Lilith? Ancient Origins by Esoterica
https://youtu.be/n1EKccz4fS0
A fairly extensive history on her historical origins
The Untold Truth of Lilith by Grunge
https://youtu.be/01guwJbp_ug
A short video intended for a popular audience
Goes over her myth and general nature
Goddess Lilith - What she likes, how to contact
https://youtu.be/75bnMRPRiDk
A simple, short to the point video that rings true to my experiences.
My Experiences Workiing with Lilith
https://youtu.be/EHol9LrpWks
One woman's account of her experience

>feminine sexuality and other weird stuff
For me it's been partially the opposite. Since working with her recently, I've been confronted with bisexual urges, and I'm still unsure how to reconcile them. It hasn't gotten to the point of feeling attracted to women in person, but nonetheless, my spiritual experiences lately have me questioning my sexual orientation.

It's embarrassing to admit, but I used to find women somewhat repulsive. I've always admired those who exemplify masculine virtues, and often saw women as the opposite, taking advantage of men's strength like parasites, subconsciously seducing their will just to satisfy their own needs. And I felt deeply ashamed of my sexuality as I recognised that same neediness within myself.

Even so, I still had to deal with gender dysphoria somehow. I already sought help from others when I was 14, but even then I could only wait as I lost things that felt important to me. But when I was 17, perhaps in a lapse of judgement, I turned to the occult. It was just a prayer to attempt to form a pact, and not even directed towards anyone in particular. But since then, my life began to change drastically, and I found relief that I didn't even think was possible.

As the wish I'd once made reached a satisfactory conclusion, and Lilith offered to guide me towards a new purpose, I thanked her and began to show my appreciation for her more. I thought I accepted myself now that I'm finally at peace with my body, only to feel lost again as spiritual experiences confront me with all sorts of sides of myself that I don't know how to reconcile. I'd have been content to ignore them for the rest of my life, but now I'm unsure how I'm supposed to proceed anymore. And although I recall her offer to guide me, I'm reluctant as I fear I'll be forced to face even more.

That's what I get for being dishonest with myself; for being so easily seduced as my contradictions are exposed.

>>33737944
I always struggled to relate to transgender people. Dysphoria was primarily a physical thing for me that ceased after my surgery, so I find the focus on stereotypes asinine and childish.

Two years ago, my older brother asked me to strangle his neck as hard as I can. He was curious if his neck muscles are stronger than my arms. I refused as it made me uncomfortable.
A year later, I felt scared as I realised how weak I am physically. But when I told my fiancé that I wanted to try building abs to boost my confidence, he was against it; he said he dislikes muscles on women. I lost motivation, as I realised I can never be as strong as him anyway.

I dislike alcohol, but knowing I'm way too hard on myself, I drank half a glass of champagne yesterday, hoping it would loosen me up a bit. The results were as agonising as I expected. It was far too little for me to lose control, but it became slightly harder for me to suppress my unwanted emotions. As they raged inside of me, I snuck away from my family and isolated myself. I forced myself to remain silent and still, but the storm inside only worsened.

When I returned, my brother noticed I was tense. He said to let out my anger by hugging him as hard as I can. So I embraced him, as if trying to crush him.
In that moment, I felt glad I'm physically weak. "I don't have to hold back. I don't have be afraid I'll hurt others, if this is all I can do", I thought.
But then, he said repeatedly: "You're strong. Those hormones didn't affect you nearly as badly as I thought." He sounded so relieved.

My brother is the strongest man I know. If I can be strong in his eyes even without training after 7 years of having less testosterone than most women, then I shouldn't belittle myself.
So I've decided to start working out and learn martial arts. It doesn't matter if I won't be as strong as I'd have been as a man; transitioning gave me other things that are more important to me. Even so, I still want to become my best self.

posts.com: I'm not certain about the definition in a Christian context, but Aristotle used this concept a lot. Baiscally, prima materia is matter but abstract, because it has no form (i.e. essence, or specificities). It cannot exist by itself because it's only the second term in things (essence/substance). It's the passive principle which contains virtually every material possibility, but which has to be "opened up".

It depends on what you mean by "idea". From a platonic point of view ("platonic ideas"), essences exist by themselves, without their material manifestations: they are principles of the material realm. Aristotle was actually against Plato's doctrine of ideas, but still believed that essence were defined (though they didn't exist in the spiritual realm).If you want to understand this doctrine, I suggest you to read Plato's Phaedo. He never exposes this doctrine in full, but it sums it up. For example, beautiful material things are only beautiful as in so for ar they are linked to the Idea (Form/Essance) of Beauty.

posts.com:
It really depends on who you are.

Some people are born or raised in such a way that they have a clean mind and few psychological problems. For them it's easy to focus and direct their mind.

Others (like how I used to be) literally live in their mind all day long, they daydream a lot and their thoughts literally control their actions and how they feel, and the worst is that they don't even realize it because they've been living like this for so long.

So I'd suggest that you just sit and observe, just sit and don't chase anything because you may be just chasing goals which are not achievable or you might be running away from harsh truths which you must first face and endure before you can move on to greater things.

Your mind is NOT you, this was a hard pill for me to take, all those thoughts which sound 100% true are just fabrications of a wild mind.

So yeah, just sit and watch, watch how your mind goes running around but don't follow it, nor make stories about it, don't try anything for there is nothing to try, just sit, your mind will come up with all crazy stuff and you will just sit there and watch it BUT without thinking "Oh I'm watching now, I'm meditating so good" for that is also thinking.

Just be the observer, and yes, with time your mind will calm down and you will be left alone or with very few thoughts, then the real "You" will start becoming clearer and that's when you can direct your focus on APing, chakras/whatever, subconscious, old forgotten memories and other things.
But you gotta first sit in silence, sit without trying to do anything. Just observe.

I've been meditating for years now and yet I can't really put into words what meditation is, I like the "meditation is deliberate focus of awareness" thing that people usually talk about.

Cultivating the ability to focus takes time. Focusing on the breath or a candle are the 2 basic exercises people recommend, it teaches you to "feel" and "observe" which are different from "thinking", it may take months to snap out of the "thinking" mode for just a second but that sole second is enough to show you that your thinking mind is not you nor your reality, it's like a radio which plays all the time and you were living with that radio open for most of your life.

>>33699233
For me the "observer" focus/mode is when you are not a slave to your thoughts and you are calmer thus you don't get dragged away by them, while the "focus" focus is the ability to focus on one thing with all your might, I say that those 2 go hand-in-hand and maybe someone could say that they are the same thing: the ability to take a step back from everything, be calm and direct your focus/observing whatever you want.

Also during my sits I remember how to feel my feelings. Feelings inhabit your body and you can feel them better if you focus on them, they usually carry forgotten memories or various insights and blissful states if you focus on them enough.

Meditation is a paradox to me, it's like a means to an end but also the end itself, it's like a vehicle which takes you places but also it's just erasing all the unnecessary noise around you to realize that all those places were always here next to you.

So sit and watch your breath, feel your body breathing, your mind will make thousands of stories about anything but just let it be, don't even label those thoughts, don't even say "I'm letting them go", just let them be and focus on your breath, on the feeling of your body breathing, your mind will say "that's stupid, analyzing these important things is better", but just focus on the breath.

>>33710828
What you say makes sense but from my own experiences I 'd say that those 2 are the same thing.

Focusing is like an ability, people are good at it or not.

You can be focused on just this moment and your surroundings without being focused on a single object. This is like being totally present, you are focused on the present, your mind isn't wandering outside of your control, thoughts may pop up but they don't take you away in daydreaming (which most people have but don't realize). Imagine that this focusing ability is like a magnifying glass, let's say that what I just described is the point "zero" of the magnifying glass, our basic reality. This is what you called the "observer" mode.

However you can zoom into one single thing using that magnifying glass, say your breath or an object. You can literally move your entire consciousness towards that thing to the point that your awareness travels there, some people say that "wizards/shamans/yogis" can move their entire consciousness towards that object and move it with their will or inhabit the body of an animal, others say that they can zoom their eyesight so much to the point that they look at the atoms of an object, some even say that they hypnotize others through this way. This is the point "1" of the glass.

Conversely you can even zoom out, you can become the whole room and even look at yourself from above, you can become your whole house and the whole city, you can focus on the whole galaxy and the whole cosmos, you can even break the linear time illusion and realize that everything is one single moment which takes place here and now. Let's say that this is the point "-1" of the glass.

That's what meditation is: Realizing that you are everything at the same time, your awareness can go everywhere since you are part of the whole, the ego is an illusion, break free from it and realize that you are whole, ignore your thoughts which most of the time are just the ego talking nonsense.

>>33699233
This post made me want to share something semi-related - an experience of mine:

For years I always wondered if non-directive meditation is the same as directive meditation, or if one was better than the other or even the "correct way to meditate".

In the non-directive kind you just sit and be aware, if something pops up you just watch it until it goes away without making stories in your mind about it.

In the directive aka focus meditation you focus on a single object and you stay with it, if something else pops up you immediately return to the object.

After practicing both for a long time I can say one thing: They both have the same result which is your thinking mind eventually quieting down, the thoughts become less and less and you are left in silence and that's when the real fun begins.

(continued in the next post)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33726002
(cont.)

I could say that non-directive would be better suited for advanced practitioners who can manage their thoughts better and are better at not being dragged away from their wandering mind, those are the practitioners who are more grounded, whose their breath is 24/7 calm. That's the "observer focus" you are talking about.

Directive is better for people who are new to meditation, those people are usually overthinkers, their breath patterns are all over the place, I'd suggest that someone who begins meditation focuses on his belly expanding or his chest or on the feeling the air makes in his throat. I suggest this because in an overthinking beginner the thoughts are coming at a very fast and strong rate. Imagine this kind of meditation like you holding on a steel pole with all your might so the tornado (thoughts) won't drag you away. That's the "focusing focus" you talked about.

So it all comes down to having a calm mind, and sitting will do this anyway, sit in the dark with no sound or anything to bother you and the thoughts WILL stop, what really helps is if you also incorporate breathwork and physical exercise in your everyday life and if you reduce screen usage (which fills your mind with lots of information), these will help you reach the "no-thought" state faster.

I remember sitting down to do "Focus on breath" meditation and various memories and bad feelings popped up, I ignored them and returned to the breath, then thoughts like "You are ignoring what's important!" popped up and I became anxious that I was using meditation to run away from my problems but I knew that I wasn't really doing that and that was just my overthinking mind not wanting to stop. Most of our problems are just thoughts in our minds and are not real at all.

So just sit and focus on the breath or on the moment, or on your body, don't think too much about it, thoughts and words are not everything, feeling is also important, feeling this moment here now.

>>33700019
Start with objects that are in another room from where you are. Then move on to physical settings in the house, imagine whole rooms and whole layouts of the house. Next, move to things that are outdoors like a park, a lake, forest or other natural settings of the sort. After that move to more dynamic situations like a busy city center, a school campus between classes when there's a lot of people walking everywhere, a busy restaurant, etc. After than imagine scenarios with yourself and other people who are immediately with you where you give each person unique physical attributes, personality traits and have them say the certain things you want them to say.

Literally that simple. Should take you sometime.

>>33732995
Shut off your PC monitor, close your laptop, back away from the desk.

Sit up right but remain in a relaxed position. Close your eyes. Take a deep breath through your nose and feel as the air travels down through your lungs and you expand your belly to fullness. Holy for 3 seconds, then slowly exhale through your pursed lips. Repeat twice more. Feel relaxed and just let your thoughts flow. Don't get in their way, just let them happen, sit back and observe. Keep breathing normally through your nose and continue to let your thoughts happen, sit back and observe them. Do this for the next 5 minutes.

There. You've done mindfulness meditation and you are going to feel better after the 5 minutes are up. Do this for the next few weeks and write down any worries, anxieties, intrusive thoughts, or recurring themes that run through your mind while meditating.

That's literally all you have to know right now. Meditation is one of those things that are better of just experiencing from the get got instead of reading about them. You can do body scan meditations, mantra meditations, visualization meditation and KUNDALINI BRO later. No need to complicate things.

Keep reading and lurking the thread for resources.

>>33728020
>I think that every religion big and small has a lot of overlap, it's a pipe dream of mine to travel the world and compare all world religions. I think because they have similar roles in their respective pantheon and are more or less major deities in their pantheon that they could be the same.
I think that's partially true. I've come to understand it that a lot of the entities we interact with when communing with a deity tend to be more like 'titles', for lack of a better terminology, than individuals. Most gods tend to embody fundamental concepts and are woven into an egregor of persona by the observations of man, but that's simply all that we're observing, not necessarily the totality of the the entity we're interacting with. So that's to say, these entities we commune with are made up of 'multiple' deities from various mythologies /pantheons because the inherent nature of what we've collectively deified is a specific facet of them. That said, I suspect there's an affinity you could try and quantify an entity with as 'more Zerus than Ares' or perhaps 'definitively Odin' if an entity primarily (but not entirely) embraces that aspect of themselves. When viewed in this light, it also helps reconcile a lot of the seemingly schizophrenic behavior they exhibit in mythologies because there's more than one entity embodying that aspect in the story and the nature of conflating the deified title with the essence of being tends to lead to the appearance of a somewhat schizophrenic-looking behavior pattern. I also suspect many of them feel very misunderstood by this 'typecasting', but that likely varies on an individual basis. As a disclaimer, this is my current working understanding after a lot of work with a lot of 'gods' but ultimately still filtering through my body's perception so not everything may be perfect.

Luffy is made of rubber to signify the ability to bounce back from any hardship with a strong enough thought/idea in your mind. From the beginning, Luffy always said that he is going to be the Pirate King. This is what he is directing his intent towards. This is where his thought energy flows, and this is the idea that the world molds itself to as a narrative.

>"Haki" is a power that lies dormant in all the world's creatures... "Presence", "fighting spirit" and "intimidation"... It is not different from the things that humans can naturally sense such as these... 'The act of not doubting'. That is strength!

The act of not doubting... This is self-explanatory at this point. Belief is fundamental to changing reality. Look into Law of Assumption and basic principles of magic.
Faith, knowing, belief, these are what give the people the ability to perform superhuman feats in the One Piece world, as well as our world.

With armament haki, users can make their body and weapons harder than steel. With observation haki one can see into the fucking future (clairvoyance). With conqueror's haki one can knock out swathes of people just due to their overwhelming kingly/conquerors presence. With enough Conquerors Haki, one can command the very weather however they see fit.

Also, Reigen is the best and you will agree by the end of the show.
